entity: Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights
entity_raw_name: I.	Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights

content.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024

children.text: Overall orientation
Mandates and background

24.1	The United Nations human rights programme is responsible for the promotion, protection, enjoyment and full realization, by all people, of all human rights. The mandate derives from the provisions of the Charter of the United Nations; the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and international human rights treaties; the Vienna Declaration and Programme of Action, including its principles and recommendations subsequently endorsed by the General Assembly in its resolution 48/121; Assembly resolution 48/141, by which the Assembly established the post of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights; the outcomes of relevant United Nations conferences and summits, including Assembly resolution 70/1, entitled “Transforming our world: the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development”; and other relevant Assembly and Human Rights Council resolutions and decisions, including the Pact for the Future (Assembly resolution 79/1) and the Proclamation of the Second International Decade for People of African Descent (Assembly resolution 79/193). In addition to international human rights law, the programme is also guided by international humanitarian law, as applicable.

24.2	The programme is guided by the principles of universality, objectivity, impartiality, indivisibility and non-selectivity in removing obstacles to the full realization of all human rights and in preventing the continuation of human rights violations, including with relevant parties. The programme has a role in supporting the implementation by Member States of the 2030 Agenda, making development equitable, sustainable and responsive to the needs of people, including in relation to conflict prevention and resolution.

24.3	The programme falls under the leadership of the High Commissioner for Human Rights, who is entrusted with the principal responsibility for the human rights activities of the Organization, under the direction and authority of the Secretary-General and within the framework of the overall competence, authority and decisions of the General Assembly and the Human Rights Council.
Strategy and external factors for 2026

24.4	In a global context affected by threats to the enjoyment of human rights by all, the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR) will continue to support the human rights mechanisms and to assist States in their efforts to comply with their human rights obligations. Increased support for and collaboration in matters regarding human rights will be provided to requesting Member States through mutually agreed bilateral frameworks. Emphasis will be placed on highlighting the importance of human rights in international and national agendas; sustaining social development and social justice (as defined in General Assembly resolution 62/10) and countering discrimination on all grounds; advancing the rights of children and women; raising awareness of human rights; responding to the needs of the vulnerable for protection; and addressing situations of international concern as identified by the Assembly, the Human Rights Council and other relevant United Nations bodies.

24.5	The Office will continue to engage with Member States and all relevant actors to assist them in their efforts to promote and protect human rights, through the provision of technical assistance, support for human rights bodies and mechanisms and, where appropriate, the establishment or strengthening of regional and country presences. Strengthened and consolidated organizational support will be provided to the Human Rights Council and its subsidiary bodies and mechanisms, the universal periodic review, the special procedures, the Human Rights Council Advisory Committee and the complaint procedure, as well as other relevant United Nations bodies. The United Nations treaty bodies will continue to be provided with services, support and advice.

24.6	With regard to cooperation with other entities at the global and regional levels, OHCHR will use multi-stakeholder partnerships to support countries in the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals and its transformative promise of leaving no one behind. The Office will continue to engage with a wide range of stakeholders, including civil society actors, such as non-governmental organizations (NGOs). It will also continue to help victims of human rights violations by managing the humanitarian funds that provide financial assistance for support services, such as rehabilitation and redress for victims of torture and slavery.

24.7	With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, OHCHR will continue to engage with the United Nations development system, both through participation in inter-agency forums and cooperation with United Nations country teams on the ground. It will also continue to cooperate with missions with a human rights component supported by the Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs and the Department of Peace Operations. It will also continue its collaboration with all the United Nations agencies and programmes in crisis situations, such as humanitarian emergencies.
24.8	With regard to the external factors, the plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
(a)	There is political will on the part of States to work with the programme;
(b)	Extrabudgetary resources will continue to be provided for the programme.

24.9	The programme integrates a gender perspective into its operational activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate. For example, subprogramme 2 will deliver capacity-building activities on the follow-up to treaty body recommendations, including those related to the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women.

24.10	In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, OHCHR will integrate disability inclusion into its operational activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate. For example, subprogramme 1 will provide expert advice on the development of standards on strengthening national human rights promotion and protection capacities as they relate to persons with disabilities.
Legislative mandates
24.11	The list below, which was reviewed in the preparation of the proposed programme budget, provides all mandates entrusted to the programme.

children.text: Evaluation activities
24.13	The following evaluations completed in 2024 by the Office have guided the proposed programme plan for 2026:
(a)	Evaluations of country programmes in Cambodia and Ukraine;
(b)	Project evaluation on addressing human rights, migration and climate change in the Sahel region.

24.14	In response to the results of the evaluations referenced above, several programme strategies, theories of change and planning frameworks have been updated or developed. For example, the theory of change for the Cambodia country programme has been strengthened, in particular on expanding the work on economic, social and cultural rights, and the multi-year strategy for the Ukraine country programme has been revised and the rapid response capacity strengthened. Lastly, in response to evaluation findings on the project in the Sahel region, the strategy of the OHCHR West Africa regional office has been updated to integrate considerations related to migration and climate change. Consistent with the formative approach of evaluations in OHCHR, the organizational learning derived from these evaluations have informed not only the country and regional presences where the evaluations took place, but also overall strategic programme directions.
24.15	The following evaluations are planned for 2026:
(a)	One cross-cutting thematic evaluation;
(b)	Three programme/project evaluations.
Programme of work
Subprogramme 1 – Human rights mainstreaming, right to development, and research and analysis
(a)	Human rights mainstreaming
Objective

24.16	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to advance the promotion and protection of all human rights through strengthened integration of all human rights into areas of work of the United Nations system.
Strategy
24.17	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:
(a)	Lead cooperation within the United Nations system for the integration of human rights into United Nations programmes and activities;

(b)	Promote the practical integration of human rights into development programmes, ensuring consistency and mutual reinforcement between United Nations-supported development activities and country engagement strategies that are jointly agreed upon with the Member States;

(c)	Contribute to developing the capability and knowledge of the United Nations system regarding relevant human rights issues through training and advice, taking into account disability and mainstreaming a gender perspective;

(d)	Develop methodological tools to facilitate the practical integration of human rights into United Nations policies, programmes and activities and, where appropriate, the advancement of the practical application of approaches to that end.
24.18	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	The United Nations system further integrating human rights into its respective programmes and activities;
(b)	Member States, pursuant to their request for support, building and strengthening national human rights promotion and protection capacities.
24.30	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will pursue a multidimensional strategy. The subprogramme will:

(a)	Enhance awareness, knowledge and understanding about the content and importance of the right to development and identify obstacles at the international, regional and national levels, through increased engagement, research, advocacy and information and educational activities, with particular focus on least developed countries, landlocked developing countries and small island developing States;

(b)	Promote the realization of the right to development across the human rights programme and encourage relevant bodies of the United Nations system, as well as funds and specialized agencies, to integrate the right to development into their work and increase focus on its practical implementation;

(c)	Strengthen partnerships and collaboration with Member States, development agencies and international development, financial and trade institutions and civil society, including NGOs and the private sector;

(d)	Encourage the promotion of the right to development in global development partnerships for the implementation by Member States of the 2030 Agenda, through cooperation and collaboration, advocacy, networking and technical advice and the establishment of partnerships, and in keeping with existing mandates;

(e)	Provide substantive support to the Human Rights Council and its subsidiary mechanisms related to the right to development, including the Intergovernmental Working Group on the Right to Development, the Expert Mechanism on the Right to Development and the Human Rights Council biennial panel on the right to development;

(f)	Provide requesting Member States with technical assistance to formulate national development strategies, such as poverty reduction papers, Sustainable Development Goals strategies and the United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Frameworks, taking into account the full respect of all human rights.

24.31	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in the integration of the promotion and protection of the right to development in global partnerships for development and policies and operational activities of relevant actors at all levels.
24.43	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Enhance the research and analysis of human rights issues, as well as the development and application of expertise in different areas, including, but not limited to, areas such as the elimination of all forms of discrimination; the rule of law, democracy and good governance; the integration of human rights into counter-terrorism and anti-trafficking measures; the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals and poverty reduction strategies and programmes; and the protection of human rights in the context of the fight against terrorism and business activities, including in the areas of new and emerging digital technologies;

(b)	Advocate for the indivisibility, interdependence and interrelatedness of all human rights, through research, policy-oriented analysis, support to standard-setting, advocacy, the compilation of best practices and improved knowledge management and knowledge-sharing; the provision of specialized human rights services; the development of methodologies, operational guidelines and tools; capacity-building and international cooperation; and the development and delivery of human rights training, for example, within the framework of the World Programme for Human Rights Education and the Global Digital Compact;

(c)	Further develop and strengthen substantive and methodological human rights expertise to support effective engagement with countries and with global and national-level partnerships, and lead efforts within the United Nations system to meet current human rights challenges;

(d)	Provide advice and assistance to requesting Member States, the United Nations system, civil society, the media and national human rights institutions in their efforts to overcome human rights implementation gaps, promote the participation and protection of rights holders, through technical cooperation, advocacy, training, policy development, analysis and advice;

(e)	Follow up and implement the Durban Declaration and Programme of Action, the outcome document of the Durban Review Conference and related declarations and the programme of activities for the implementation of the Second International Decade for People of African Descent (2025–2034).
24.44	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in enhanced knowledge, awareness and understanding of human rights issues.

Programme performance in 2024
Increased mainstreaming of human rights in intergovernmental processes on the digital sphere and digital technologies

24.19	The Human Rights Council, in its resolution 53/29, reaffirmed the need for all stakeholders to collaborate in a more concerted way in addressing the possible impacts, opportunities and challenges of new and emerging digital technologies with regard to the promotion and protection of human rights. In 2024, the subprogramme enhanced its engagement with Member States to integrate human rights considerations into intergovernmental processes addressing the use of digital technologies. For example, the subprogramme provided advice in the negotiation process for the Global Digital Compact and for the United Nations Convention against Cybercrime. In addition, in 2024, pursuant to the abovementioned resolution, the subprogramme prepared a report for consideration by the Council (A/HRC/56/45) mapping the work and recommendations of the Council, OHCHR, the human rights treaty bodies and the special procedures of the Council in the field of human rights and new and emerging digital technologies, including artificial intelligence. The subprogramme also finalized the development of the Guidance of the Secretary-General on Human Rights Due Diligence for Digital Technology Use and convened an expert consultation on applying the Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights to the activities of technology companies.
24.20	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 24.2).
Table 24.2 – Performance measure

table_content.text: 2022 (actual)
2023 (actual)

children.text: Increased integration of human rights norms and standards into intergovernmental processes related to financing for development

24.32	Drawing on the efforts to operationalize the right to development, the subprogramme supports efforts by Member States to reform the current international financial architecture with the objective to leave no one behind. The subprogramme worked to ensure that human rights are integrated across intergovernmental processes relevant to the United Nations Framework Convention on International Tax Cooperation and to inform the negotiations of the Fourth International Conference on Financing for Development on human rights issues related to debt, international financial institutions and development cooperation through, inter alia, submissions of policy briefs, coordination with stakeholders, including civil society, and advocacy with co-facilitators of the Conference and Member States.

children.text: Recognition of the value of human rights in climate action by a growing number of stakeholders

24.45	The subprogramme has undertaken extensive research and analysis with respect to advancing human rights solutions in addressing issues related to climate change, particularly in the context of accountability and remediation. The 2024 reports of the Secretary-General on loss and damage (mandated by resolution 53/6), and of the High Commissioner for Human Rights on the legacy of nuclear testing in the Marshall Islands (mandated by resolution 51/35), explored the potential application of elements of a transitional justice approach to efforts to ensure accountability and access to remedy.

children.text: Result 3: increased promotion and protection of human rights in national policies and practices through the economic, social and cultural rights knowledge hub – Proposed programme plan for 2026

24.25	In response to Human Rights Council resolution 54/22, the subprogramme established the economic, social and cultural rights knowledge hub dedicated to technical assistance and capacity-building, to consolidate best practices and know-how in promoting and protecting economic, social and cultural rights, within the context of addressing inequalities for Member States and relevant stakeholders.
Lessons learned and planned change

24.26	The lesson for the subprogramme was that the collection of baseline data and the inclusion of metrics can enhance the sharing of best practices. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will strengthen the collection of data to document measurable improvements for the integration of human rights in national policies and practices. The subprogramme will focus its technical assistance and capacity- building on practices that have a positive impact on the realization of economic, social and cultural rights, and will increase peer-learning and improve the availability of knowledge products.
24.27	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 24.5).

24.39	The lesson for the subprogramme was the need to address specific challenges and enhance the practical application of the right to development at both regional and national levels. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will work closely with regional and national actors, to develop practical tools and methodologies to operationalize the right to development and will facilitate the identification and sharing of practical experiences.
24.40	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 24.9).

24.52	The lesson learned for the subprogramme was that while there is an extensive body of work produced by the United Nations and its human rights mechanisms concerning human rights and digital technologies, more efforts are needed to support the practical implementation of recommendations of United Nations human rights bodies and processes. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will provide hands-on, context-specific advice to Member States, international organizations and businesses, upon request, to develop, use and govern technology in line with human rights norms and standards. A key measure in this regard will be the establishment of an advisory service on digital technologies and human rights, as recognized in the Global Digital Compact, which will support Member States and other stakeholders in areas such as legislation and regulation, as well as how to design large-scale digital infrastructure projects.
24.53	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 24.13).

children.text: Objective

24.16	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to advance the promotion and protection of all human rights through strengthened integration of all human rights into areas of work of the United Nations system.
Strategy
24.17	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:
(a)	Lead cooperation within the United Nations system for the integration of human rights into United Nations programmes and activities;

(b)	Promote the practical integration of human rights into development programmes, ensuring consistency and mutual reinforcement between United Nations-supported development activities and country engagement strategies that are jointly agreed upon with the Member States;

(c)	Contribute to developing the capability and knowledge of the United Nations system regarding relevant human rights issues through training and advice, taking into account disability and mainstreaming a gender perspective;

(d)	Develop methodological tools to facilitate the practical integration of human rights into United Nations policies, programmes and activities and, where appropriate, the advancement of the practical application of approaches to that end.
24.18	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	The United Nations system further integrating human rights into its respective programmes and activities;
(b)	Member States, pursuant to their request for support, building and strengthening national human rights promotion and protection capacities.
24.30	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will pursue a multidimensional strategy. The subprogramme will:

(a)	Enhance awareness, knowledge and understanding about the content and importance of the right to development and identify obstacles at the international, regional and national levels, through increased engagement, research, advocacy and information and educational activities, with particular focus on least developed countries, landlocked developing countries and small island developing States;

(b)	Promote the realization of the right to development across the human rights programme and encourage relevant bodies of the United Nations system, as well as funds and specialized agencies, to integrate the right to development into their work and increase focus on its practical implementation;

(c)	Strengthen partnerships and collaboration with Member States, development agencies and international development, financial and trade institutions and civil society, including NGOs and the private sector;

(d)	Encourage the promotion of the right to development in global development partnerships for the implementation by Member States of the 2030 Agenda, through cooperation and collaboration, advocacy, networking and technical advice and the establishment of partnerships, and in keeping with existing mandates;

(e)	Provide substantive support to the Human Rights Council and its subsidiary mechanisms related to the right to development, including the Intergovernmental Working Group on the Right to Development, the Expert Mechanism on the Right to Development and the Human Rights Council biennial panel on the right to development;

(f)	Provide requesting Member States with technical assistance to formulate national development strategies, such as poverty reduction papers, Sustainable Development Goals strategies and the United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Frameworks, taking into account the full respect of all human rights.

24.31	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in the integration of the promotion and protection of the right to development in global partnerships for development and policies and operational activities of relevant actors at all levels.
24.43	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Enhance the research and analysis of human rights issues, as well as the development and application of expertise in different areas, including, but not limited to, areas such as the elimination of all forms of discrimination; the rule of law, democracy and good governance; the integration of human rights into counter-terrorism and anti-trafficking measures; the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals and poverty reduction strategies and programmes; and the protection of human rights in the context of the fight against terrorism and business activities, including in the areas of new and emerging digital technologies;

(b)	Advocate for the indivisibility, interdependence and interrelatedness of all human rights, through research, policy-oriented analysis, support to standard-setting, advocacy, the compilation of best practices and improved knowledge management and knowledge-sharing; the provision of specialized human rights services; the development of methodologies, operational guidelines and tools; capacity-building and international cooperation; and the development and delivery of human rights training, for example, within the framework of the World Programme for Human Rights Education and the Global Digital Compact;

(c)	Further develop and strengthen substantive and methodological human rights expertise to support effective engagement with countries and with global and national-level partnerships, and lead efforts within the United Nations system to meet current human rights challenges;

(d)	Provide advice and assistance to requesting Member States, the United Nations system, civil society, the media and national human rights institutions in their efforts to overcome human rights implementation gaps, promote the participation and protection of rights holders, through technical cooperation, advocacy, training, policy development, analysis and advice;

(e)	Follow up and implement the Durban Declaration and Programme of Action, the outcome document of the Durban Review Conference and related declarations and the programme of activities for the implementation of the Second International Decade for People of African Descent (2025–2034).
24.44	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in enhanced knowledge, awareness and understanding of human rights issues.

24.29	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to advance the promotion and protection of the effective enjoyment by all of all human rights through the effective realization of the right to development.
Strategy
24.17	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:
(a)	Lead cooperation within the United Nations system for the integration of human rights into United Nations programmes and activities;

(b)	Promote the practical integration of human rights into development programmes, ensuring consistency and mutual reinforcement between United Nations-supported development activities and country engagement strategies that are jointly agreed upon with the Member States;

(c)	Contribute to developing the capability and knowledge of the United Nations system regarding relevant human rights issues through training and advice, taking into account disability and mainstreaming a gender perspective;

(d)	Develop methodological tools to facilitate the practical integration of human rights into United Nations policies, programmes and activities and, where appropriate, the advancement of the practical application of approaches to that end.
24.18	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	The United Nations system further integrating human rights into its respective programmes and activities;
(b)	Member States, pursuant to their request for support, building and strengthening national human rights promotion and protection capacities.
24.30	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will pursue a multidimensional strategy. The subprogramme will:

(b)	Promote the realization of the right to development across the human rights programme and encourage relevant bodies of the United Nations system, as well as funds and specialized agencies, to integrate the right to development into their work and increase focus on its practical implementation;

(c)	Strengthen partnerships and collaboration with Member States, development agencies and international development, financial and trade institutions and civil society, including NGOs and the private sector;

(d)	Encourage the promotion of the right to development in global development partnerships for the implementation by Member States of the 2030 Agenda, through cooperation and collaboration, advocacy, networking and technical advice and the establishment of partnerships, and in keeping with existing mandates;

(e)	Provide substantive support to the Human Rights Council and its subsidiary mechanisms related to the right to development, including the Intergovernmental Working Group on the Right to Development, the Expert Mechanism on the Right to Development and the Human Rights Council biennial panel on the right to development;

(f)	Provide requesting Member States with technical assistance to formulate national development strategies, such as poverty reduction papers, Sustainable Development Goals strategies and the United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Frameworks, taking into account the full respect of all human rights.

24.31	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in the integration of the promotion and protection of the right to development in global partnerships for development and policies and operational activities of relevant actors at all levels.
24.43	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Enhance the research and analysis of human rights issues, as well as the development and application of expertise in different areas, including, but not limited to, areas such as the elimination of all forms of discrimination; the rule of law, democracy and good governance; the integration of human rights into counter-terrorism and anti-trafficking measures; the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals and poverty reduction strategies and programmes; and the protection of human rights in the context of the fight against terrorism and business activities, including in the areas of new and emerging digital technologies;

(b)	Advocate for the indivisibility, interdependence and interrelatedness of all human rights, through research, policy-oriented analysis, support to standard-setting, advocacy, the compilation of best practices and improved knowledge management and knowledge-sharing; the provision of specialized human rights services; the development of methodologies, operational guidelines and tools; capacity-building and international cooperation; and the development and delivery of human rights training, for example, within the framework of the World Programme for Human Rights Education and the Global Digital Compact;

(c)	Further develop and strengthen substantive and methodological human rights expertise to support effective engagement with countries and with global and national-level partnerships, and lead efforts within the United Nations system to meet current human rights challenges;

(d)	Provide advice and assistance to requesting Member States, the United Nations system, civil society, the media and national human rights institutions in their efforts to overcome human rights implementation gaps, promote the participation and protection of rights holders, through technical cooperation, advocacy, training, policy development, analysis and advice;

(e)	Follow up and implement the Durban Declaration and Programme of Action, the outcome document of the Durban Review Conference and related declarations and the programme of activities for the implementation of the Second International Decade for People of African Descent (2025–2034).
24.44	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in enhanced knowledge, awareness and understanding of human rights issues.

24.42	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to advance the promotion and protection of the effective enjoyment by all of all human rights through increased knowledge, awareness and understanding.
Strategy
24.17	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:
(a)	Lead cooperation within the United Nations system for the integration of human rights into United Nations programmes and activities;

(b)	Promote the practical integration of human rights into development programmes, ensuring consistency and mutual reinforcement between United Nations-supported development activities and country engagement strategies that are jointly agreed upon with the Member States;

(c)	Contribute to developing the capability and knowledge of the United Nations system regarding relevant human rights issues through training and advice, taking into account disability and mainstreaming a gender perspective;

(d)	Develop methodological tools to facilitate the practical integration of human rights into United Nations policies, programmes and activities and, where appropriate, the advancement of the practical application of approaches to that end.
24.18	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	The United Nations system further integrating human rights into its respective programmes and activities;
(b)	Member States, pursuant to their request for support, building and strengthening national human rights promotion and protection capacities.
24.30	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will pursue a multidimensional strategy. The subprogramme will:

(a)	Enhance awareness, knowledge and understanding about the content and importance of the right to development and identify obstacles at the international, regional and national levels, through increased engagement, research, advocacy and information and educational activities, with particular focus on least developed countries, landlocked developing countries and small island developing States;

(b)	Promote the realization of the right to development across the human rights programme and encourage relevant bodies of the United Nations system, as well as funds and specialized agencies, to integrate the right to development into their work and increase focus on its practical implementation;

(c)	Strengthen partnerships and collaboration with Member States, development agencies and international development, financial and trade institutions and civil society, including NGOs and the private sector;

(d)	Encourage the promotion of the right to development in global development partnerships for the implementation by Member States of the 2030 Agenda, through cooperation and collaboration, advocacy, networking and technical advice and the establishment of partnerships, and in keeping with existing mandates;

(e)	Provide substantive support to the Human Rights Council and its subsidiary mechanisms related to the right to development, including the Intergovernmental Working Group on the Right to Development, the Expert Mechanism on the Right to Development and the Human Rights Council biennial panel on the right to development;

(f)	Provide requesting Member States with technical assistance to formulate national development strategies, such as poverty reduction papers, Sustainable Development Goals strategies and the United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Frameworks, taking into account the full respect of all human rights.

24.31	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in the integration of the promotion and protection of the right to development in global partnerships for development and policies and operational activities of relevant actors at all levels.
24.43	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Enhance the research and analysis of human rights issues, as well as the development and application of expertise in different areas, including, but not limited to, areas such as the elimination of all forms of discrimination; the rule of law, democracy and good governance; the integration of human rights into counter-terrorism and anti-trafficking measures; the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals and poverty reduction strategies and programmes; and the protection of human rights in the context of the fight against terrorism and business activities, including in the areas of new and emerging digital technologies;

(b)	Advocate for the indivisibility, interdependence and interrelatedness of all human rights, through research, policy-oriented analysis, support to standard-setting, advocacy, the compilation of best practices and improved knowledge management and knowledge-sharing; the provision of specialized human rights services; the development of methodologies, operational guidelines and tools; capacity-building and international cooperation; and the development and delivery of human rights training, for example, within the framework of the World Programme for Human Rights Education and the Global Digital Compact;

(c)	Further develop and strengthen substantive and methodological human rights expertise to support effective engagement with countries and with global and national-level partnerships, and lead efforts within the United Nations system to meet current human rights challenges;

(d)	Provide advice and assistance to requesting Member States, the United Nations system, civil society, the media and national human rights institutions in their efforts to overcome human rights implementation gaps, promote the participation and protection of rights holders, through technical cooperation, advocacy, training, policy development, analysis and advice;

(e)	Follow up and implement the Durban Declaration and Programme of Action, the outcome document of the Durban Review Conference and related declarations and the programme of activities for the implementation of the Second International Decade for People of African Descent (2025–2034).
24.44	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in enhanced knowledge, awareness and understanding of human rights issues.
Programme performance in 2024
Increased mainstreaming of human rights in intergovernmental processes on the digital sphere and digital technologies

24.19	The Human Rights Council, in its resolution 53/29, reaffirmed the need for all stakeholders to collaborate in a more concerted way in addressing the possible impacts, opportunities and challenges of new and emerging digital technologies with regard to the promotion and protection of human rights. In 2024, the subprogramme enhanced its engagement with Member States to integrate human rights considerations into intergovernmental processes addressing the use of digital technologies. For example, the subprogramme provided advice in the negotiation process for the Global Digital Compact and for the United Nations Convention against Cybercrime. In addition, in 2024, pursuant to the abovementioned resolution, the subprogramme prepared a report for consideration by the Council (A/HRC/56/45) mapping the work and recommendations of the Council, OHCHR, the human rights treaty bodies and the special procedures of the Council in the field of human rights and new and emerging digital technologies, including artificial intelligence. The subprogramme also finalized the development of the Guidance of the Secretary-General on Human Rights Due Diligence for Digital Technology Use and convened an expert consultation on applying the Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights to the activities of technology companies.

children.text: Increased integration of human rights norms and standards into intergovernmental processes related to financing for development

24.32	Drawing on the efforts to operationalize the right to development, the subprogramme supports efforts by Member States to reform the current international financial architecture with the objective to leave no one behind. The subprogramme worked to ensure that human rights are integrated across intergovernmental processes relevant to the United Nations Framework Convention on International Tax Cooperation and to inform the negotiations of the Fourth International Conference on Financing for Development on human rights issues related to debt, international financial institutions and development cooperation through, inter alia, submissions of policy briefs, coordination with stakeholders, including civil society, and advocacy with co-facilitators of the Conference and Member States.

children.text: Recognition of the value of human rights in climate action by a growing number of stakeholders

24.45	The subprogramme has undertaken extensive research and analysis with respect to advancing human rights solutions in addressing issues related to climate change, particularly in the context of accountability and remediation. The 2024 reports of the Secretary-General on loss and damage (mandated by resolution 53/6), and of the High Commissioner for Human Rights on the legacy of nuclear testing in the Marshall Islands (mandated by resolution 51/35), explored the potential application of elements of a transitional justice approach to efforts to ensure accountability and access to remedy.

children.text: Result 3: increased promotion and protection of human rights in national policies and practices through the economic, social and cultural rights knowledge hub – Proposed programme plan for 2026

24.25	In response to Human Rights Council resolution 54/22, the subprogramme established the economic, social and cultural rights knowledge hub dedicated to technical assistance and capacity-building, to consolidate best practices and know-how in promoting and protecting economic, social and cultural rights, within the context of addressing inequalities for Member States and relevant stakeholders.
Lessons learned and planned change

24.26	The lesson for the subprogramme was that the collection of baseline data and the inclusion of metrics can enhance the sharing of best practices. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will strengthen the collection of data to document measurable improvements for the integration of human rights in national policies and practices. The subprogramme will focus its technical assistance and capacity- building on practices that have a positive impact on the realization of economic, social and cultural rights, and will increase peer-learning and improve the availability of knowledge products.
24.27	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 24.5).

24.39	The lesson for the subprogramme was the need to address specific challenges and enhance the practical application of the right to development at both regional and national levels. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will work closely with regional and national actors, to develop practical tools and methodologies to operationalize the right to development and will facilitate the identification and sharing of practical experiences.
24.40	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 24.9).

24.52	The lesson learned for the subprogramme was that while there is an extensive body of work produced by the United Nations and its human rights mechanisms concerning human rights and digital technologies, more efforts are needed to support the practical implementation of recommendations of United Nations human rights bodies and processes. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will provide hands-on, context-specific advice to Member States, international organizations and businesses, upon request, to develop, use and govern technology in line with human rights norms and standards. A key measure in this regard will be the establishment of an advisory service on digital technologies and human rights, as recognized in the Global Digital Compact, which will support Member States and other stakeholders in areas such as legislation and regulation, as well as how to design large-scale digital infrastructure projects.
24.53	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 24.13).

children.text: Objective

24.16	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to advance the promotion and protection of all human rights through strengthened integration of all human rights into areas of work of the United Nations system.
Strategy
24.17	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:
(a)	Lead cooperation within the United Nations system for the integration of human rights into United Nations programmes and activities;

(b)	Promote the practical integration of human rights into development programmes, ensuring consistency and mutual reinforcement between United Nations-supported development activities and country engagement strategies that are jointly agreed upon with the Member States;

(c)	Contribute to developing the capability and knowledge of the United Nations system regarding relevant human rights issues through training and advice, taking into account disability and mainstreaming a gender perspective;

(d)	Develop methodological tools to facilitate the practical integration of human rights into United Nations policies, programmes and activities and, where appropriate, the advancement of the practical application of approaches to that end.
24.18	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	The United Nations system further integrating human rights into its respective programmes and activities;
(b)	Member States, pursuant to their request for support, building and strengthening national human rights promotion and protection capacities.
24.30	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will pursue a multidimensional strategy. The subprogramme will:

(a)	Enhance awareness, knowledge and understanding about the content and importance of the right to development and identify obstacles at the international, regional and national levels, through increased engagement, research, advocacy and information and educational activities, with particular focus on least developed countries, landlocked developing countries and small island developing States;

(b)	Promote the realization of the right to development across the human rights programme and encourage relevant bodies of the United Nations system, as well as funds and specialized agencies, to integrate the right to development into their work and increase focus on its practical implementation;

(c)	Strengthen partnerships and collaboration with Member States, development agencies and international development, financial and trade institutions and civil society, including NGOs and the private sector;

(d)	Encourage the promotion of the right to development in global development partnerships for the implementation by Member States of the 2030 Agenda, through cooperation and collaboration, advocacy, networking and technical advice and the establishment of partnerships, and in keeping with existing mandates;

(e)	Provide substantive support to the Human Rights Council and its subsidiary mechanisms related to the right to development, including the Intergovernmental Working Group on the Right to Development, the Expert Mechanism on the Right to Development and the Human Rights Council biennial panel on the right to development;

(f)	Provide requesting Member States with technical assistance to formulate national development strategies, such as poverty reduction papers, Sustainable Development Goals strategies and the United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Frameworks, taking into account the full respect of all human rights.

24.31	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in the integration of the promotion and protection of the right to development in global partnerships for development and policies and operational activities of relevant actors at all levels.
24.43	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Enhance the research and analysis of human rights issues, as well as the development and application of expertise in different areas, including, but not limited to, areas such as the elimination of all forms of discrimination; the rule of law, democracy and good governance; the integration of human rights into counter-terrorism and anti-trafficking measures; the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals and poverty reduction strategies and programmes; and the protection of human rights in the context of the fight against terrorism and business activities, including in the areas of new and emerging digital technologies;

(b)	Advocate for the indivisibility, interdependence and interrelatedness of all human rights, through research, policy-oriented analysis, support to standard-setting, advocacy, the compilation of best practices and improved knowledge management and knowledge-sharing; the provision of specialized human rights services; the development of methodologies, operational guidelines and tools; capacity-building and international cooperation; and the development and delivery of human rights training, for example, within the framework of the World Programme for Human Rights Education and the Global Digital Compact;

(c)	Further develop and strengthen substantive and methodological human rights expertise to support effective engagement with countries and with global and national-level partnerships, and lead efforts within the United Nations system to meet current human rights challenges;

(d)	Provide advice and assistance to requesting Member States, the United Nations system, civil society, the media and national human rights institutions in their efforts to overcome human rights implementation gaps, promote the participation and protection of rights holders, through technical cooperation, advocacy, training, policy development, analysis and advice;

(e)	Follow up and implement the Durban Declaration and Programme of Action, the outcome document of the Durban Review Conference and related declarations and the programme of activities for the implementation of the Second International Decade for People of African Descent (2025–2034).
24.44	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in enhanced knowledge, awareness and understanding of human rights issues.

Programme performance in 2024
Increased mainstreaming of human rights in intergovernmental processes on the digital sphere and digital technologies

24.19	The Human Rights Council, in its resolution 53/29, reaffirmed the need for all stakeholders to collaborate in a more concerted way in addressing the possible impacts, opportunities and challenges of new and emerging digital technologies with regard to the promotion and protection of human rights. In 2024, the subprogramme enhanced its engagement with Member States to integrate human rights considerations into intergovernmental processes addressing the use of digital technologies. For example, the subprogramme provided advice in the negotiation process for the Global Digital Compact and for the United Nations Convention against Cybercrime. In addition, in 2024, pursuant to the abovementioned resolution, the subprogramme prepared a report for consideration by the Council (A/HRC/56/45) mapping the work and recommendations of the Council, OHCHR, the human rights treaty bodies and the special procedures of the Council in the field of human rights and new and emerging digital technologies, including artificial intelligence. The subprogramme also finalized the development of the Guidance of the Secretary-General on Human Rights Due Diligence for Digital Technology Use and convened an expert consultation on applying the Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights to the activities of technology companies.
24.20	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 24.2).

children.text: Increased integration of human rights norms and standards into intergovernmental processes related to financing for development

24.32	Drawing on the efforts to operationalize the right to development, the subprogramme supports efforts by Member States to reform the current international financial architecture with the objective to leave no one behind. The subprogramme worked to ensure that human rights are integrated across intergovernmental processes relevant to the United Nations Framework Convention on International Tax Cooperation and to inform the negotiations of the Fourth International Conference on Financing for Development on human rights issues related to debt, international financial institutions and development cooperation through, inter alia, submissions of policy briefs, coordination with stakeholders, including civil society, and advocacy with co-facilitators of the Conference and Member States.
24.33	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 24.7).

children.text: Recognition of the value of human rights in climate action by a growing number of stakeholders

24.45	The subprogramme has undertaken extensive research and analysis with respect to advancing human rights solutions in addressing issues related to climate change, particularly in the context of accountability and remediation. The 2024 reports of the Secretary-General on loss and damage (mandated by resolution 53/6), and of the High Commissioner for Human Rights on the legacy of nuclear testing in the Marshall Islands (mandated by resolution 51/35), explored the potential application of elements of a transitional justice approach to efforts to ensure accountability and access to remedy.
24.46	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 24.11).
Table 24.11 – Performance measure

table_content.text: 2022 (actual)
2023 (actual)
2024 (actual)
Member States increased their commitments to the right to a healthy environment and to integrate human rights in key environmental negotiations and their outcomes

The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, in its Sixth Assessment Report, found that adaptation and mitigation actions that prioritise, among other aspects, rights-based approaches, lead to more sustainable outcomes and support transformative change
The Global Framework on Chemicals – for a Planet Free of Harm from Chemicals and Waste reflected a recognition of the linkages between human rights and pollution

The importance of human rights and equity-based approaches to loss and damage from climate change was recognized by stakeholders, including Member States, during meetings of the Human Rights Council and the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
The Human Rights Council adopted resolutions 56/8 on human rights and climate change and 57/26 on the human rights implications of the nuclear legacy in the Marshall Islands

children.text: Result 3: increased promotion and protection of human rights in national policies and practices through the economic, social and cultural rights knowledge hub – Proposed programme plan for 2026

24.25	In response to Human Rights Council resolution 54/22, the subprogramme established the economic, social and cultural rights knowledge hub dedicated to technical assistance and capacity-building, to consolidate best practices and know-how in promoting and protecting economic, social and cultural rights, within the context of addressing inequalities for Member States and relevant stakeholders.
Lessons learned and planned change

24.26	The lesson for the subprogramme was that the collection of baseline data and the inclusion of metrics can enhance the sharing of best practices. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will strengthen the collection of data to document measurable improvements for the integration of human rights in national policies and practices. The subprogramme will focus its technical assistance and capacity- building on practices that have a positive impact on the realization of economic, social and cultural rights, and will increase peer-learning and improve the availability of knowledge products.
24.27	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 24.5).

24.39	The lesson for the subprogramme was the need to address specific challenges and enhance the practical application of the right to development at both regional and national levels. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will work closely with regional and national actors, to develop practical tools and methodologies to operationalize the right to development and will facilitate the identification and sharing of practical experiences.
24.40	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 24.9).

24.52	The lesson learned for the subprogramme was that while there is an extensive body of work produced by the United Nations and its human rights mechanisms concerning human rights and digital technologies, more efforts are needed to support the practical implementation of recommendations of United Nations human rights bodies and processes. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will provide hands-on, context-specific advice to Member States, international organizations and businesses, upon request, to develop, use and govern technology in line with human rights norms and standards. A key measure in this regard will be the establishment of an advisory service on digital technologies and human rights, as recognized in the Global Digital Compact, which will support Member States and other stakeholders in areas such as legislation and regulation, as well as how to design large-scale digital infrastructure projects.
24.53	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 24.13).

In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will work closely with regional and national actors, to develop practical tools and methodologies to operationalize the right to development and will facilitate the identification and sharing of practical experiences.
24.40	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 24.9).

24.52	The lesson learned for the subprogramme was that while there is an extensive body of work produced by the United Nations and its human rights mechanisms concerning human rights and digital technologies, more efforts are needed to support the practical implementation of recommendations of United Nations human rights bodies and processes. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will provide hands-on, context-specific advice to Member States, international organizations and businesses, upon request, to develop, use and govern technology in line with human rights norms and standards. A key measure in this regard will be the establishment of an advisory service on digital technologies and human rights, as recognized in the Global Digital Compact, which will support Member States and other stakeholders in areas such as legislation and regulation, as well as how to design large-scale digital infrastructure projects.
24.53	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 24.13).

children.text: Subprogramme 2 – Supporting human rights treaty bodies
Objective

24.55	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to advance the promotion and protection of the effective enjoyment of all human rights by all, in particular through support and advice to the human rights treaty bodies and by increasing awareness among national and international actors of the international human rights treaties and the work of treaty bodies.
Strategy
24.56	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Provide support for the review of Member State reports and the preparation of general comments; for the conduct of inquiries and country visits, including to places of deprivation of liberty where provided for in the treaty or upon request of Member States; for early warning and urgent action procedures and the processing of individual complaints, urgent actions and inter-State complaints; as well as assistance and advice to the national preventive mechanisms;
(b)	Support the efforts of treaty bodies to improve and enhance their working methods;

(c)	Engage with Member States, national human rights institutions, United Nations agencies, NGOs and other actors to enhance awareness, knowledge and understanding of the treaty bodies’ work and outputs and to promote ratification of international human rights treaties;

(d)	Support States Parties, upon request, in building their capacity to implement their treaty obligations and in the preparation and timely submission of their national reports, as well as in in establishing or strengthening national mechanisms for reporting and follow-up through the exchange of experiences and good practices;

(e)	Assist treaty bodies in their efforts to address reprisals when they occur, and in their responses to claims and acts of intimidation or reprisals against individuals and groups for their contribution to the work of the human rights treaty bodies.
24.57	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Efficient and effective functioning of the treaty bodies;
(b)	Enhanced cooperation of stakeholders at all levels with treaty bodies in accordance with their working methods and mandates.
Programme performance in 2024
Increased number of ratifications of international human rights treaties

24.58	Building upon the ratification campaign started in 2023 under the Human Rights 75 initiative, the subprogramme continued its advocacy work and support to Member States contemplating ratifying international human rights treaties and their optional protocols. Through regional and cross-regional events, the subprogramme contributed to enhancing knowledge of the content of the instruments and Member States’ obligations thereunder and facilitated exchanges of experiences between Member States.
24.59	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 24.III).
Figure 24.III – Performance measure: new ratifications of international human rights treaties (annual)
Planned results for 2026
Result 1: enhanced participation of delegates in reviews by treaty bodies of reports of States Parties – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

24.60	The subprogramme’s work contributed to 44 hybrid meetings with interpretation, which did not meet the planned target of 226 meetings. The target was not met as there was a return to in-person meetings of treaty bodies except for those specifically mandated as hybrid, such as the official dialogues with State Party delegations, mandated by paragraph 23 of General Assembly resolution 68/268.
24.61	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 24.IV).
Figure 24.IV – Performance measure: number of hybrid meetings of treaty bodies with interpretation (annual)
Result 2: increased international cooperation to support national mechanisms for implementation, reporting and follow-up – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

24.62	The subprogramme’s work contributed to identifying good practices in 10 countries on implementation, reporting and follow-up to the recommendations of the international human rights mechanisms, which did not meet the planned target of 10 countries that shared practices through the knowledge hub. The target was not met because the establishment of the virtual knowledge hub was postponed to 2025 by Human Rights Council decision 55/115.
24.63	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 24.V).

Figure 24.V – Performance measure: number of countries that have shared practices on implementation, reporting and follow up to the international human rights mechanisms through the knowledge hub (annual)
Result 3: improved access by State Parties and stakeholders to the recommendations of treaty bodies to facilitate their implementation – Proposed programme plan for 2026

24.64	The subprogramme has launched digital tools, including the treaty body database and the Universal Human Rights Index, to enhance the capacity of Member States, rights holders and other stakeholders to access information and claim their rights.
Lessons learned and planned change

24.65	The lesson for the subprogramme was that more synergies need to be created in developing new online tools that are linked to existing online platforms, such as the treaty body database and the Universal Human Rights Index. Another lesson was to ensure that the basic infrastructure, such as the treaty body database, is continuously improved and up to date. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will further work on updating the treaty body database and enhancing the interconnectedness between different online tools to facilitate ease of access.
24.66	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 24.VI).
Figure 24.VI – Performance measure: number of users of the treaty body database (annual)

children.text: Subprogramme 3 – Advisory services, technical cooperation and field activities
Objective

24.68	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to advance the promotion and protection of the effective enjoyment by all of all human rights, through enhanced capacity-building, including through assistance to requesting Member States.
Strategy
24.69	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Provide Member States, upon their request, and stakeholders at the national and regional levels with human rights legal advice, education, awareness-raising and training through mutually agreed advisory services and technical cooperation programmes, including in the implementation of the recommendations to which Member States have agreed in the universal periodic review process;

(b)	Improve cooperation within the United Nations system for the protection and promotion of human rights, through joint activities, the deployment of human rights officers, interaction with OHCHR programmes in the field and relevant United Nations human rights mechanisms;

(c)	Continue to deploy human rights experts and fact-finding missions, including in humanitarian emergencies, at the request of an affected country or as mandated by the relevant United Nations legislative bodies;

(d)	Assist the Human Rights Council and its mechanisms, as well as other policymaking bodies and the treaty bodies, in preparing for and following up on their dialogue with Member States and ensure the efficient and effective functioning of thematic and country-specific special procedures by following human rights developments.
24.70	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Enhanced national capacities to translate international human rights obligations into effective laws, regulations and policies and meet the challenges to the full realization of human rights;

(b)	Enhanced capacity of United Nations country teams, field presences, peacekeeping operations and peacebuilding activities to assist requesting countries in their efforts to develop national human rights protection systems, guided, inter alia, by the recommendations of the international human rights mechanisms;
(c)	Prevention of human rights violations, including in situations of large-scale crisis.
Programme performance in 2024
Strengthened partnership between the United Nations and the African Union

24.71	In November 2023, the African Union-United Nations Joint Framework on Human Rights was signed by the African Union Chairperson and the United Nations Secretary-General, underlining the shared commitment to the promotion and protection of human rights on the continent. As a framework of cooperation on human rights matters, it aims to enhance the support provided by both organizations to Member States, national human rights institutions, the judiciary and civil society. In 2024, the subprogramme supported the development of an implementation matrix for the Framework, laying the foundation for African Union-United Nations collaboration on human rights for the next four years. The subprogramme also facilitated a review of the Human Rights Analytical Framework to strengthen the Continental Early Warning System of the African Union to better integrate human rights in conflict prevention.
24.72	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 24.16).

24.73	The subprogramme’s work contributed to 68 least developed countries and small island developing States implementing recommendations emanating from international human rights mechanisms, which met the planned target.

Result 2: strengthened effectiveness of national human rights institutions in line with the Paris Principles – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

24.75	The subprogramme’s work contributed to the establishment or strengthening of the effectiveness of 84 national human rights institutions, in line with the Principles Relating to the Status of National Human Rights Institutions (Paris Principles), which exceeded the planned target of 80.
24.76	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 24.VIII).
Figure 24.VIII – Performance measure: number of national human rights institutions established or strengthened in line with the Paris Principles (cumulative)
Result 3: increased technical cooperation to support Member States in the Caribbean Community in their efforts to promote, protect and fulfil human rights – Proposed programme plan for 2026

24.77	The Human Rights Council, in its resolution 54/33, welcomed the initiative of the Government of The Bahamas to host a regional office of OHCHR for the Caribbean Community, in particular to undertake technical assistance and capacity-building activities in accordance with international human rights obligations and to support efforts to promote, protect and fulfil human rights within the region.
Lessons learned and planned change

24.78	The lesson for the subprogramme was that the direct engagement with Member States from least developed countries and small island developing States led to increased requests for in-region technical assistance. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will scale up its support to Member States, including to improve their engagement with United Nations human rights mechanisms, including through technical cooperation aimed at national capacity-building, public information and education, with a view to exchanging information and experience in the field of human rights.

children.text: Subprogramme 4 – Supporting the Human Rights Council, its subsidiary bodies and mechanisms
Objective

24.81	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to advance the promotion and protection of the effective enjoyment by all of all human rights, by providing strengthened support and advice to the Human Rights Council and its subsidiary bodies and mechanisms, including the Human Rights Council Advisory Committee, the special procedures, the universal periodic review and the complaint procedure.
Strategy
24.82	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:
(a)	Research and develop analytical information and knowledge in support of the thematic special procedures and the universal periodic review mechanism to enhance their effectiveness;

(b)	Support and provide thematic expertise for fact-finding missions and special procedure mandate holders’ country visits, including through enhanced cooperation within the programme, analysis of gaps in the implementation of international human rights instruments, promotion of observance for international human rights standards and provision of timely advice for addressing gross and systematic violations of human rights;
(c)	Support the international human rights mechanisms in their efforts to promote the implementation of the 2030 Agenda in accordance with the human rights obligations of Member States;

(d)	Disseminate knowledge of the conclusions, recommendations and other outcomes of the universal periodic review, as well as the findings and methodology of the thematic special procedures, and improve coordination among mandate holders and other mechanisms of the human rights machinery;

(e)	Support partnerships and reinforce dialogue and cooperation with Governments, national human rights institutions, civil society organizations, United Nations system and the United Nations human rights machinery and cooperating policymaking bodies, including to support follow-up to the findings and recommendations of the special procedure mandate holders and the outcomes of the universal periodic review;
(f)	Provide assistance to Member States within the universal periodic review framework.
24.83	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Enhanced and effective functioning of the Human Rights Council and its subsidiary bodies and mechanisms, including more effective deliberations and decision-making processes;
(b)	Enhanced cooperation at all levels with stakeholders that can benefit from and/or contribute to the work of the Human Rights Council and its subsidiary bodies and mechanisms.
Programme performance in 2024
Increased cooperation of Member States in Special Procedures communications

24.84	The special procedures of the Human Rights Council are independent experts with mandates to report and advise on human rights from a thematic or country-specific perspective. In 2024, the subprogramme contributed to enhanced impact of the work of special procedures. Following focused engagement with Member States, an increase in Member States’ cooperation in responding to communications on alleged human rights violations was recorded in 2024. In addition, Vanuatu accepted a visit for the first time in its history, reducing the list of countries never visited by a mandate holder to 20. Similarly, six countries accepted a visit after more than five years (Benin, Guinea-Bissau, Marshall Islands, Samoa, Thailand and the United Arab Emirates). Special procedures’ communications reached a higher number of individuals and victims of alleged human rights violations. Furthermore, special procedures’ legal analysis interventions contributed to improving conformity of various domestic legislation with international human rights norms and standards.
24.85	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 24.19).

children.text: Planned results for 2026
Result 1: enhanced participation of the least developed countries and small island developing States in the Human Rights Council – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

24.86	The subprogramme’s work contributed to participation of 43 delegates from least developed countries and small island developing States in the Human Rights Council, which exceeded the planned target of 30 delegates.
24.87	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 24.IX).
Figure 24.IX – Performance measure: number of delegates from least developed countries and small island developing States participating in Human Rights Council sessions (annual)
Result 2: enhanced contribution of national human rights institutions to the universal periodic review mechanism – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

24.88	The subprogramme’s work contributed to the submission of 30 contributions to the universal periodic review mechanism from national human rights institutions accredited in full compliance with the Paris Principles, which did not meet the target of 41 written and oral submissions. The target was not met due to the fact that several of the countries reviewed in 2024 did not have a national human rights institution accredited with “A” status.
24.89	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 24.X).
Figure 24.X – Performance measure: number of written and oral submissions made by national human rights institutions during the universal periodic review (annual)
Result 3: enhanced engagement of United Nations country teams with the universal periodic review mechanism – Proposed programme plan for 2026

24.90	The subprogramme works with United Nations country teams, in close cooperation with the United Nations Development Coordination Office, to encourage and support their active participation in the universal periodic review.
Lessons learned and planned change

24.91	The lesson for the subprogramme was that holding regular briefings sessions with the United Nations system at the country level, as well as bilateral meetings with resident coordinators, can enhance the participation and contribution by United Nations country teams. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will expand the above-mentioned practices and combine them with regular sharing of information on timelines and modalities of engagement to encourage their active participation in the universal periodic review.
24.92	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 24.XI).
Figure 24.XI – Performance measure: number of written submissions made by United Nations country teams during the universal periodic review (annual)
