24.97	As shown in table 24.24 (1), resource changes reflect a net decrease of $7,847,500, as follows:

(a)	Executive direction and management (decrease of $200,000). The decrease of $200,000 comprises decreases under other staff costs ($104,500), travel of representatives ($33,300), travel on official business ($18,800) and grants and contributions ($43,400), which relate to the removal of non-recurrent provisions associated with Human Rights Council resolution 55/17 that were approved for 2025 and are no longer required in 2026;

(b)	Subprogramme 1, Human rights mainstreaming, right to development, and research and analysis (decrease of $6,219,600). The net decrease of $6,219,600 comprises: (i) a decrease of $7,080,200 under other staff costs ($4,957,100), consultants ($501,100), travel of representatives ($428,900), travel of staff ($169,400), contractual services ($87,300), general operating expenses ($156,000), furniture and equipment ($51,700) and grants and contributions ($728,700) relating to the removal of non-recurrent provisions associated with Human Rights Council resolutions from its fifty-fifth, fifty-sixth and fifty-seventh regular sessions that were approved for 2025 and are no longer required in 2026; and (ii) an increase of $860,600 under posts, which relates to the higher provision at continuing vacancy rates for 5 Human Rights Officers (P-4) and 5 Human Rights Officers (P-3) established in 2025 pursuant to Human Rights Council resolutions 55/29, 57/19 and 57/28, which were subject to a 50 per cent vacancy rate in accordance with the established practice for newly established posts;

(c)	Subprogramme 2, Supporting human rights treaty bodies (decrease of $186,900). The decrease of $186,900 under other staff costs ($78,900), travel of representatives ($30,100) and grants and contributions ($77,900) relates to the removal of non-recurrent provisions associated with Human Rights Council decision 55/115 (postponing the implementation of mandates contained in Human Rights Council resolution 51/33) that were approved for 2025 and are no longer required in 2026;

(d)	Subprogramme 3, Advisory services, technical cooperation and field activities (decrease of $1,016,300). The net decrease of $1,016,300 comprises: (i) a decrease of 2,064,900 under other staff costs ($1,483,500), consultants ($95,900), travel of representatives ($21,200), travel of staff ($170,800), contractual services ($130,500), general operating expenses ($60,700), supplies and materials ($6,500), furniture and equipment ($20,000) and grants and contributions ($75,800) relating to the removal of non-recurrent provisions associated with Human Rights Council resolutions from its fifty-fifth, fifty-sixth and fifty-seventh regular sessions that were approved for 2025 and are no longer required in 2026; and (ii) an increase of $1,048,600 under posts, which relates to the higher provision at continuing vacancy rates for 2 Human Rights Officers (P-3), 9 Associate Human Rights Officers (P-2), 6 Human Rights Officers (National Professional Officer) and 6 Programme Management Officers (National Professional Officer) established in 2025 pursuant to Human Rights Council resolution 55/28 and General Assembly resolution 79/257, which were subject to a 50 per cent vacancy rate in accordance with the established practice for newly established posts;

(e)	Subprogramme 4, Supporting the Human Rights Council, its subsidiary bodies and mechanisms (decrease of $622,900). The decrease of $622,900 under other staff costs ($482,100), travel of representatives ($31,300), travel of staff ($17,300), furniture and equipment ($3,200) and grants and contributions ($89,000) relates to the removal of non-recurrent provisions associated with Human Rights Council resolutions 52/26, 56/10, 57/13 and President’s statement 18/1 that were approved for 2025 and are no longer required in 2026;

(f)	Programme support (increase of $398,200). The net increase of $398,200 comprises: (i) a decrease of $102,800 under other staff costs ($99,600) and furniture and equipment ($3,200) relating to the removal of non-recurrent provisions associated with Human Rights Council President’s statement 18/1 that were approved for 2025 and are no longer required in 2026; and (ii) an increase of $501,000 under posts, which relates to the higher provision at continuing vacancy rates for 2 Administrative Officers (P-3), 1 Legal Officer (P-3), 1 Information Systems Officer (P-3), 1 Security Coordinator Officer (P-3) and 1 Associate Finance Officer (P-2) established in 2025 pursuant to General Assembly resolution 79/257, which were subject to a 50 per cent vacancy rate in accordance with the established practice for newly established posts.

The net increase of $3,509,900 comprises: (i) an increase of $4,842,800 under posts ($4,071,800), which relates to the establishment of 44 posts (2 D-1, 3 P-4, 20 P-3, 7 P-2, 10 National Professional Officer, 1 General Service (Other level) and 1 Local level) and one conversion (1 P-3), contractual services ($87,000), general operating expenses ($521,600), supplies and materials ($7,600), and furniture and equipment ($154,800) pursuant to General Assembly resolution 79/1, explained in further detail in paragraph 24.99 and annex IV; (ii) an increase under contractual services ($3,300) relating to requirements for Human Rights Council resolution 57/23; and (iii) a decrease of $1,336,200 under posts ($552,300) relating to the redeployment of 21 posts (1 D-1, 2 P-5, 3 P-4, 8 P-3 and 7 P-2), other staff costs ($688,900) relating to the redeployment of 15 general temporary assistance positions (4 P-4 and 11 P-3) and one conversion (P-3), and consultants and experts ($95,000) pursuant to General Assembly resolution 79/1;

(e)	Subprogramme 4, Supporting the Human Rights Council, its subsidiary bodies and mechanisms (increase of $1,401,400). The net increase of $1,401,400 comprises: (i) an increase under posts ($1,342,800), which relates to the establishment of 12 posts (2 P-4, 7 P-3 and 3 P-2) pursuant to General Assembly resolution 79/1, explained in further detail in paragraph 24.99 and annex IV; (ii) an increase under other staff costs ($53,800) and travel of representatives ($7,600) relating to requirements for Human Rights Council resolutions 49/32 and 53/9; and (iii) a decrease of $2,800 relating to the redeployment of 1 post (1 P-4) pursuant to General Assembly resolution 79/1;

(f)	Programme support (increase of $38,400). An increase of $38,400 under furniture and equipment relates to the requests for new posts under subprogramme 4, pursuant to the General Assembly resolution 79/1, explained in further detail in paragraph 24.99 and annex IV.
The Pact for the Future (General Assembly resolution 79/1)

24.99	With regard to the resource requirements under subprogrammes 1, 2, 3, 4 and programme support, the General Assembly, in its resolution 79/1, paragraph 74 (a), requested the Secretary-General to assess the need for adequate, predictable, increased and sustainable financing of the United Nations human rights mechanisms, including OHCHR, for efficient and effective mandate delivery to enable them to respond to the range of human rights challenges facing the international community with impartiality, objectivity and non-selectivity. The proposed programme budget of OHCHR for 2026 focuses on adequately resourcing the Office’s regional presences to support more efficient and effective global mandate delivery that is impartial, objective and non-selective, including shifting resources from headquarters to the regions and prioritizing core support for the Human Rights Council and the special procedures. Additional information is provided in annex IV. The proposal covers the following:

(a)	Strengthening regional presences. To address the critical priority gaps of over-reliance on voluntary contributions and inadequate leadership and staffing levels in regional presences, a tailored approach based on the needs of each region is proposed, to include redeploying existing regular budget and extrabudgetary posts and positions from Geneva and building on existing capacities at the regional level. Reinforcing regional offices would enhance mandate delivery and address increasing demand for human rights services and technical assistance while achieving significant cost savings and efficiency gains. This includes the following:

(i)	A proposal to relocate the Regional Office for Europe from Brussels to Vienna, which involves expanding that Office’s scope to become the Regional Office for Europe and Central Asia, thereby establishing it as a central hub for the entire region. This strategic move aims to enhance operational efficiency and foster stronger regional collaboration. As the new regional hub, the Office will serve as a focal point for coordinating human rights initiatives, providing technical assistance, and facilitating dialogue among countries in Europe and Central Asia, ultimately strengthening the impact and reach of OHCHR in addressing regional human rights challenges;

(ii)	To enhance the regional engagement of OHCHR, a proposal for strengthening seven key locations: Addis Ababa, Bangkok, Beirut, Dakar, Panama City, Pretoria and Vienna. The proposal includes the establishment of 47 posts (2 D-1, 4 P-4, 22 P-3, 7 P-2, 10 National Professional Officer, 1 General Service (Other level) and 1 Local level); and redeploying posts and positions from Geneva and Brussels to seven regional offices, including 28 established posts and 1 temporary post (1 D-1, 1 P-5, 8 P-4, 12 P-3 and 7 P-2), converting and redeploying 1 general temporary assistance position (1 P-3), and redeploying 16 general temporary positions (4 P-4 and 12 P-3). In terms of the requirements for senior posts, two locations are already headed by a D-1 (Addis Ababa, funded by extrabudgetary resources, and Panama City, funded by the regular budget) and it is proposed that three locations be headed by a D-1 (new posts in Bangkok and Beirut and the redeployment of 1 post from Geneva to Vienna). The location in Dakar will be headed by a P-5, who will report to the existing regular-budget funded D-1 in Yaoundé, who leads the Subregional Centre for Human Rights and Democracy in Central Africa. The location in Pretoria will be headed by a P-5, who will report to the existing D-1 in Addis Ababa. Concerning non-staff resources, resources under contractual services, general operating expenses, supplies and materials and furniture and equipment under the different regional offices are also proposed, to be offset by efficiency gains, including gains from the proposed redeployment of personnel from Geneva to the regional offices;

(b)	Strengthening human rights mechanisms. The guiding principle is that all mandated activities should be covered in their entirety by the regular budget. In that context, the current proposal for 2026 related to the mandates deriving from the Pact for the Future includes 5 new posts (2 P-4 and 3 P-3) required to provide support and advice to the Human Rights Council, its President and its Bureau, and to Member States and other stakeholders on policy matters, rules and procedures, as well as media and communication support. Concerning the special procedures, 7 new posts (4 P-3 and 3 P-2) would support country visits and consultations, draft thematic reports and carry out other mandated activities led by multiple special procedures established by the Human Rights Council. Concerning non-staff resources, resources under furniture and equipment are also proposed under programme support.

24.100	A summary by object of expenditure of the complete budget proposal for OHCHR under the Pact for the Future and other new mandates pursuant to Human Rights Council resolutions and other General Assembly resolutions is provided in table 24.28 below.

children.text: Other changes
24.101	As shown in table 24.24 (1), resource changes reflect a net decrease of $20,900, which affects mainly the operational requirements projected for 2026, as follows:

(a)	Subprogramme 3, Advisory services, technical cooperation and field activities (decrease of $34,800). The net decrease of $34,800 comprises: (i) an increase of $334,500 under posts ($173,300), which relates to the conversion of 1 post (P-3) supporting the Independent Expert on the situation of human rights in the Central African Republic, and other staff costs ($161,200) related to additional general temporary assistance to support the Special Rapporteur on the situation of human rights in Myanmar, replacing the use of consultants; and (ii) a decrease of $369,300 related to the conversion and redeployment of one general temporary assistance position ($199,100), consultants ($161,200), reflecting the reduced use of consultants to support the Special Rapporteur on the situation of human rights in Myanmar, and a correction of duty station under posts ($9,000) related to Human Rights Council resolution 55/28;

(b)	Programme support (increase of $13,900). The increase of $13,900 results from an increase under contractual services ($13,900) reflecting the higher standard price of the core software package for non-field personnel outside United Nations Headquarters.
Other assessed resources

24.102	As reflected in tables 24.24 (2) and 24.25 (2), other assessed resources amount to $3,175,100, including eight posts and five general temporary assistance positions. The resources would complement regular budget resources and provide for the requirements indicated in report A/79/783.
Extrabudgetary resources

24.103	As reflected in tables 24.14 (3) and 24.15 (3), extrabudgetary resources amount to $238,346,300. The resources would complement regular budget resources and would be used mainly to provide for 1,264 posts (6 D-1, 73 P-5, 205 P-4, 292 P-3, 45 P-2/1, 314 National Professional Officer, 10 General Service (Principal level) and 319 General Service (Other level)) to perform mainly the functions of supporting research and analysis for developing conceptual links between human rights and development; the work for the United Nations Voluntary Fund for Victims of Torture, the United Nations voluntary trust fund on contemporary forms of slavery and the United Nations Special Fund established pursuant to the Optional Protocol to the Convention against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment, as well as the work of the treaty bodies; and activities relating to the overall executive direction and management of OHCHR, including planning, monitoring and evaluation, external outreach services and the New York Office. In addition, non-post resources would be used for supporting the majority of the Office’s work undertaken in the field at more than 100 locations worldwide, the work of the three trust funds established by the Human Rights Council (Voluntary Fund for Participation in the Universal Periodic Review, Voluntary Fund for Financial and Technical Assistance in the Implementation of the Universal Periodic Review and Voluntary Technical Assistance Trust Fund to Support the Participation of Least Developed Countries and Small Island Developing States in the Work of the Human Rights Council). Programme Support and Management Services is also provided with extrabudgetary resources to complement its service delivery capacity in all OHCHR locations around the world.

24.104	The Office receives both cash and in-kind contributions, which complement regular budget resources. Anticipated in-kind contributions would provide for rent-free premises with an estimated value of $1,088,700 and the provision of an armoured vehicle and running costs with an estimated value of $52,300.

24.105	The extrabudgetary resources for this entity are subject to the oversight of the High Commissioner of Human Rights as head of entity of OHCHR, in accordance with the delegation of authority by the Secretary-General.

Executive direction and management

24.108	The executive direction and management component comprises the Executive Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights, the Policy, Planning, Monitoring and Evaluation Service, the External Outreach Service and the New York Office.

24.109	The High Commissioner is the United Nations official with principal responsibility for United Nations human rights activities, in accordance with the mandate entrusted to the High Commissioner by the General Assembly in its resolution 48/141. The High Commissioner advises the Secretary-General on the policies of the United Nations concerning human rights and is responsible for coordinating human rights activities throughout the United Nations system and for rationalizing, adapting, strengthening and streamlining the United Nations system in the area of human rights, with a view to improving its efficiency and effectiveness.
24.110	The High Commissioner provides overall executive direction, management, policy guidance and leadership for the implementation of the United Nations human rights programme.

24.111	The Deputy High Commissioner assists the High Commissioner in the overall direction and management of OHCHR. In addition, the Deputy’s responsibilities include the supervision of OHCHR divisions in support of the High Commissioner and the supervision of OHCHR-wide functions centralized in executive direction and management and programme support. The Assistant Secretary-General, the head of the New York Office, allows for participation at the appropriate level in executive decision-making processes and ensures principal-level representation and access to high-level policy discussions, improving the overall efficiency and effectiveness of OHCHR.

24.112	In accordance with the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, in particular target 12.6 of the Sustainable Development Goals, in which organizations are encouraged to integrate sustainability information into their reporting cycles, and in compliance with the cross-cutting mandate set out in paragraph 19 of General Assembly resolution 72/219, OHCHR continues to integrate environmental management practices into its operations, programming and management functions. The Office, including its field presences, reports and offsets its greenhouse gas emissions annually and is committed to improving its environmental performance and reducing its climate impact. An organizational effectiveness action plan is in place for the period 2024–2027 to establish an environmental management system in order to digitize work processes, promote sustainable travel, reduce waste and energy and water consumption, and engage staff, partners and stakeholders in environmental and climate action.

24.113	Information on the timely submission of documentation and advance booking for air travel is reflected in table 24.31. OHCHR continues to use the available data to monitor and manage compliance with the advance purchase of tickets for air travel policy. Similarly, OHCHR will increase its efforts to raise awareness among staff of the requirement to improve the timeliness of submission of its documents.

Programme support
24.119	The programme support component comprises Programme Support and Management Services and the Safety and Security Section.

24.120	In order for OHCHR to implement in full its mandate at both headquarters and its more than 100 field presences, Programme Support and Management Services provides support in the form of budgeting and financial management; recruitment and human resources management; safety and security, procurement, asset management and general logistical support for field activities; travel and information technology; and staff development and training. This includes support for staff members and members of intergovernmental and expert bodies, as well as for special rapporteurs, special representatives and independent experts, and the management of premises; and information management and technology support, including technical development and operational maintenance of the OHCHR websites, specialized databases and other systems.
